idioms.text: as far as I know | as far as I can remember, see, tell, etc.
idioms.sense: used to say that you think you know, remember, understand, etc. something but you cannot be completely sure, especially because you do not know all the facts
examples: As far as we knew, there was no cause for concern.
As far as I can see, you've done nothing wrong.
She lived in Chicago, as far as I can remember.

idioms.text: before you know where you are
idioms.sense: very quickly or suddenly
examples: We were whisked off in a taxi before we knew where we were.

idioms.sense: to have no way of realizing or being aware that you have done something wrong
examples: ‘I'm sorry, I called when you were in bed.’ ‘Don't worry—you weren't to know.’

idioms.text: better the devil you know (than the devil you don’t)
idioms.sense: used to say that it is easier and wiser to stay in a bad situation that you know and can deal with rather than change to a new situation that may be much worse

idioms.text: for all you, I, they, etc. know
idioms.sense: used to emphasize that you do not know something and that it is not important to you
examples: She could be dead for all I know.

idioms.text: God/goodness/Heaven knows (informal) Some people may find this use of God offensive.
idioms.sense: used to emphasize that you do not know somethingused to emphasize the truth of what you are saying
examples: God knows what else they might find.
‘Where are they?’ ‘Goodness knows.’
She ought to pass the exam—goodness knows she's been working hard enough.

idioms.sense: to be confident that you know something, especially when you actually do not
examples: He thinks he knows all the answers.

idioms.text: have/know something off pat (British English) (North American English have/know something down pat)
idioms.sense: to know something perfectly so that you can repeat it at any time without having to think about it
examples: He had all the answers off pat.

idioms.sense: to be in poor condition
examples: Our car has seen better days!

idioms.text: I don’t know how, why, etc…
idioms.sense: used to criticize somebody’s behaviour
examples: I don't know how you can say things like that.

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody the true facts about a situation, especially when these are not known by other people
examples: If the truth be known, I was afraid to tell anyone.

idioms.sense: used to agree with somebody or to show sympathyused to introduce a new idea or suggestion
examples: ‘What a ridiculous situation!’ ‘I know.’
I know, let's see what's on at the theatre.

idioms.text: know something as well as I do
idioms.sense: used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something
examples: You know as well as I do that you're being unreasonable.

idioms.sense: to know somebody/something extremely well
examples: She must know the play backwards by now.

idioms.sense: to know what should be done, etc. better than other people
examples: The doctor told you to stay in bed, and she knows best.

idioms.text: know better (than that/than to do something)
idioms.sense: to be sensible enough not to do something
examples: He knows better than to judge by appearances.

idioms.sense: to recognize somebody without knowing them well
to have information or evidence that the opposite is true
examples: He says he doesn't care about what the critics write, but I know different.

idioms.sense: to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it
examples: He knew full well what she thought of it.

idioms.text: know somebody/something inside out | know somebody/something like the back of your hand
idioms.sense: to be very familiar with somebody/something
examples: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

idioms.sense: to have very clear and definite ideas about what you want to do
to know a lot about a particular subject or job

idioms.text: know/tell somebody a thing or two (about somebody/something)
idioms.sense: to know/tell somebody some useful, interesting or surprising information about somebody/something
examples: She's been married five times, so she knows a thing or two about men!

idioms.sense: to know something because of something unpleasant that has happened to you
examples: He's a ruthless businessman, as I know to my cost.

idioms.sense: to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.
to have knowledge about something from your own experience
examples: I’ve lived in China, so I know what I’m talking about.

idioms.text: know which side your bread is buttered
idioms.sense: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself

idioms.text: let it be known/make it known that…
idioms.sense: to make sure that people are informed about something, especially by getting somebody else to tell them
examples: The President has let it be known that he does not intend to run for election again.

idioms.sense: to tell somebody about something
examples: I don't know if I can come, but I'll let you know tomorrow.
Let me know how I can help.
Please let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

idioms.sense: used to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

idioms.sense: used to say that you do not know the answer to something
examples: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

idioms.sense: to introduce yourself to somebody
examples: I made myself known to the hotel manager.

idioms.sense: to behave badly, usually because you have not been taught the correct way to behave
examples: Don’t blame the children—they don’t know any better.

idioms.text: not know your arse from your elbow
idioms.sense: to be very stupid; to have absolutely no skill
to know nothing about a subject
examples: I don’t know beans about making movies.

idioms.text: not know the first thing about somebody/something
idioms.sense: to know nothing at all about somebody/something
examples: I’m afraid I don’t know the first thing about cars.

idioms.text: not know, etc. the first thing about something/somebody
idioms.sense: to know nothing at all about something/somebody
examples: We’ve lived next to him for years, but we still don’t know the first thing about him.

idioms.sense: to not know at all who somebody is
to be so surprised by something that you do not know how to react
to feel very embarrassed and not know how to react

idioms.text: not know whether you’re coming or going
idioms.sense: to be so excited or confused that you cannot behave or think in a sensible way
to have an easy life without realizing how easy it is
examples: You people without kids don't know you're born.

idioms.sense: to take no interest in something because you do not care about it or it is too much trouble
examples: I've tried to ask her advice, but she doesn't want to know (= about my problems).
‘How much was it?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= it is better if you don't know).

idioms.sense: old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did
to show somebody/know/learn how a particular job should be done
used to say that it is impossible to say what might happen
examples: There's no knowing how he'll react.

idioms.sense: used to say that somebody knows nothing about the subject you are talking about
examples: What does he know about football, anyway?

idioms.sense: used to express surprise
examples: Well, what do you know? Look who's here!

idioms.sense: (know) what things are useful, important, etc.
examples: She certainly knows what's what.

idioms.sense: used when you are thinking of what to say nextused to show that what you are referring to is known or understood by the person you are speaking toused to emphasize something that you are saying
examples: Well, you know, it's difficult to explain.
Guess who I've just seen? Maggie! You know—Jim's wife.
You know that restaurant round the corner? It's closed down.
I'm not stupid, you know.

idioms.sense: used to introduce an interesting or surprising opinion, piece of news, etc.
examples: You know something? I've never really enjoyed Christmas.

idioms.sense: used to refer to somebody/something without mentioning a name
used to say that you can never be certain about what will happen in the future, especially when you are suggesting that something good might happen

senses.text: used to refer to an animal or a thing that has already been mentioned or that is being talked about now
examples: ‘Where's your car?’ ‘It's in the garage.’

If it's convenient I can come tomorrow.

I like it here.
It's Jim who's the clever one.

idioms.sense: this/that is the important point, reason, etc.this/that is the end
examples: That's just it—I can't work when you're making so much noise.
I'm afraid that's it—we've lost.

idioms.sense: the expected event is just going to happenthis is the main point
examples: Well, this is it! Wish me luck.
‘You're doing too much.’ ‘Well, this is it. I can't cope with any more work.’
